text: it seems like you can't walk into a
movie theater these days without
encountering some vision of apocalypse
usually one using a lot of loud big
special effects but none of these
visions of catastrophe is quite as
haunting or as effective as the one put
forward in a movie called La Jetee
directed by Chris Marker in 1962 it's 28
minutes long and it consists of
voice-over narration a musical score and
a series of black and white still
photographs if you've seen Terry
Gilliam's 12 monkeys the story may seem
a little bit familiar down in the
tunnels underneath the ruined city of
Paris in the wake of a devastating
global war a man is subjected to
time-travel experiments he's pitched
forward into the future and then
backward into the past where he falls in
love and tries to figure out the
mysteries of his own existence a girl
could be the one he is yelling for
he crosses her path I'll appear he sees
her face in a car smiling more images
pour out a mix museum perhaps the Museum
of his memory
time travel is a familiar theme in
movies maybe even an obsession it's
everywhere these days from Terminator to
Star Trek to the Time Traveler's Wife
and one reason for this may be that
movies themselves are a kind of time
travel when you watch a movie you're
projected back into a past and a movie
as it's being made is projecting itself
into the future but unlike a lot of
those other films la jet√©e is more than
just science fiction speculation about
the mechanics of time travel it's a
philosophical investigation into the way
that our minds perceive and perhaps even
construct our experience of time itself
time rolls back again the moment happens
once more this time she is near him he
says something she doesn't mind she
answers they have no memories no plans
time builds itself painlessly around
them neurologists believed that our
sense of the continuity of time is
something of an illusion created by our
perception which of course is also true
of movies every movie is a series of
still images that our perception
connects the great thing about logit a
is that it makes this overt it makes us
conscious of this process most movies
present a total package of image music
words fused together logitech pulls them
apart you have Trevor Duncan's
extraordinary evocative score the
beautiful strange haunting images that
Chris Marker has made and this
voice-over narration which has moments
of poetry in it and you have to put all
of these things together yourself but at
one point in this film Chris Marker
allows us to see how at some
extraordinary times such as say when we
fall in love all of these elements come
together to move
you
